conclusion: We have a suitcase with a mass of 15 kg, and someone is pulling it with an oblique upward force of 90 N to make it move uniformly on a horizontal surface. The angle between this pulling force and the horizontal direction is θ, and we need to find both μ and θ. Given that sin 37° = 0.6 and g = 10 m/s².
The net force acting on it is zero.
The suitcase is on a horizontal surface.

premise: Forces acting on the suitcase: weight (mg) downward, normal force (N) upward, pulling force (F) at an angle θ, frictional force (f) opposite to motion.
conclusion: The frictional force is proportional to the normal force, f = μN.

premise: Pulling force is 90 N at an angle θ.
conclusion: Resolve the pulling force into horizontal (F_h = F cos θ) and vertical (F_v = F sin θ) components.

premise: Net force in vertical direction is zero.
conclusion: mg - N + F sin θ = 0, so N = mg + F sin θ.

premise: Net force in horizontal direction is zero.
conclusion: F cos θ - f = 0, so F cos θ = μN.
F cos θ - μ(mg + F sin θ) = 0.

premise: Minimum value of the pulling force is 90 N.
conclusion: At minimum force, horizontal component of the pulling force is equal to the frictional force.

premise: F cos θ = μ(mg + F sin θ).
conclusion: Plug in F = 90 N, m = 15 kg, g = 10 m/s²: 90 cos θ = μ(150 + 90 sin θ).

premise: Consider the condition for minimum force.
conclusion: Derivative of F with respect to θ is zero at minimum force.

premise: F = 90 N, solve for μ and θ.
